awd_titl_txt: Analysis of Discrete Structures and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This project treats a broad range of problems in the analysis of discrete structures ranging from classical problems in analytic number theory concerning the gap distribution between primes and the shape of number fields, to the mixing behavior of random walks on groups.  A central theme is the interaction between techniques from analytic number theory, probability, and combinatorics.  The principal investigator recently made a breakthrough by using probabilistic techniques to solve a famous problem of Paul Erdos in combinatorial number theory, and part of the investigation will develop applications of this result.  The problems studied have applications to cryptography and quantum computation.  Funding is to be used to support the research of a group of undergraduate and graduate students and to support outreach efforts aimed at high school and undergraduate students interested in problem solving and beginning research.

The project includes problems on automorphic forms, sieve methods, and the analysis of random walks on groups.  The  projects are split between topics in pure analytic number theory, such as the use of automorphic forms to study the lattice shape of the ring of integers of number fields, projects which use techniques common in analytic number theory, like the theory of exponential sums and oscillatory integrals, to study the asymptotic mixing of Markov chains and other limit problems in probability, and projects which use more purely probabilistic techniques.  A significant part of the project extends the theory of zeta functions of prehomogeneous vector spaces in studying low degree number fields.  A variety of modern analytic techniques are to be employed, including the use of automorphic forms on higher rank groups, partition functions from statistical mechanics, the distribution of points on nilmanifolds, and the theory of products of random matrices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award received funding from combinatorics, probability and number theory, and in fact the intellectual merit of the award is based in part on using a set of analytic techniques to solve old problems and conjectures in several areas. Building on the PI's Solution of the Minimum Modulus Problem for Covering Systems, an 80 year old problem of Paul Erdös for which Erdös had offered $1000, together with Pace Nielsen the PI solved another problem of Erdös on covering systems, proving that any distinct covering system has a modulus divisible by 2 or 3. This paper appeared in Duke Math Journal. Joint with P. Diaconis, the PI solved a conjecture of E. Breuillard regarding the local limit theorem on nilpotent Lie groups, a paper which is now appearing in the Annales Scientifiques de l'École Normale Supérieure. Joint with D. Jerison and L. Levine the PI resolved the mixing behavior of the abelian sandpile model on a torus, a problem which had been open since the 80s. Joint with an undergraduate, H. Son, the PI extended this to a result uniform in the dimension, treating various boundary and lattice geometry conditions. Joint with another undergraduate student Y. Chu, the PI solved a conjecture of Diaconis on the mixing behavior of a 15 puzzle, a problem which had also been open 30 years. This work was written up in the national media in Quanta.  Part of the work on the award involved making analytic improvements to the papers of M. Bhargava on low degree number fields cited in his Fields medal. A highlight of this work is a joint paper with Eun Hye Lee that gives the highest degree example of a zeta function subconvex in t-aspect.  This work is novel as a first example using some of Bhargava's methods to prove subconvexity. Joint with Lee, the PI also has resolved a conjecture discussed by Bhargava and Gross regarding an irregularity in the distribution of lattice shapes of rings and number fields. The PI has also refined the local analysis of Bhargava's papers, and introduced new methods of studying the distribution of shapes of rings of integers using spectral analysis. The PI uses a broad range of analytic techniques, including the theory of automorphic forms, Fourier analysis, and discrete probability. The primary intellectual merit of the award rests on solving old and well-known conjectures and making contributions to a central line of research in number theory concerning Bhargava's work on enumerating orbits in representation spaces. The research on the award was presented at major conferences, including the Joint Math Meetings, at the American Institute of Math and Microsoft Research and in seminars in the US and internationally.  In part for the research on the award, the PI won a Sloan Fellowship in Mathematics, a Faculty Award from Stony Brook University, and has now been promoted to tenure.

 

Part of the broader impact of the award concerned involvement with high school and undergraduate students both in problem solving and in research. The PI ran Stony Brook's Putnam seminar during the award, and helped to run the Stony Brook Math Circle for area high school students interested in problem solving. Two Stony Brook undergraduates won fellowships to do undergraduate research with the PI, resulting in papers in the Annals of Probability, Mathematics of Computation and Quanta, and introducing new techniques and resolving open problems. The PI has been mentoring a high school student interested in doing research in group theory, especially considering the rubics cube. During the award, Stony Brook's valedictorian recognized the PI as the faculty who had influenced him at the university's awards ceremony.  The PI has also introduced new activities in the Stony Brook math department, by starting an Analysis Seminar and teaching graduate topics courses in analytic number theory and probability theory.
